awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Team: Sustainable Battery Electrode Manufacturing with High Active Material Loading
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a battery electrode modification method to enhance lithium (Li)-ion battery performance. The most widely used cathode materials in the Li-ion battery for electrical vehicles are nickel (Ni)-rich oxides. However, the low chemical and electrochemical stability, the large inactive material requirement (typically 10-15%), and the high cost needed for the storage of these materials due to the water adsorption on the surface hinder the further advancement and large-scale implementation of the Ni-rich material for the battery cathode. Through the proposed technology, the assembled cathode achieves higher chemical and electrochemical stability, ultra-low inactive material content in the cathode (less than 1%), and a significant reduction in the storage cost to repel water in the air due to the stability in ambient air.  This new electrode manufacturing method may enable longer driving mileage of electric vehicles and a longer battery life span.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a new battery cathode manufacturing process, leveraging a unique gas phase conducting polymer coating technique using oxidative chemical vapor deposition (oCVD). A multi-functional conducting polymer prepared through oCVD achieves ultra-high active materials concentration (up to 99%) due to the high conductivity and adhesive function of the oCVD polymers.  The oCVD polymers protect the cathode surface by limiting unfavorable reactions and phases such as detrimental cathode/electrolyte interfacial phases and water adsorption on the cathode surface. The increased active material concentration and the protection ability effectively contribute to the enhancement of lithium-ion battery capacity (10% higher), rate performance (14% higher), and cycle life (550% longer), compared to those without oCVD polymer coating.  The proposed battery manufacturing technique is expected to mitigate the performance degradation issues for high nickel cathode materials where a trade-off exists between high battery capacity and high performance-retention due to the interfacial phases and water adsorption.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The development of advanced Lithium-Ion Batteries (LIBs) for Electric Vehicles (EVs) is critical to addressing some of the most pressing challenges including climate change, energy security, and urban air quality. The higher energy density, longer cycle life, and improved safety of next-generation LIBs are the key components of the EV revolution, compared to traditional battery technologies. These attributes are essential for extending the driving range of EVs, reducing charging times, and making EVs a more viable and attractive option for consumers. By enhancing the performance and cost-effectiveness of LIBs, we can accelerate the adoption of EVs, thereby reducing greenhouse gas emissions and our dependence on fossil fuels, fostering a cleaner and more sustainable transportation sector.

The I-Corps program has been instrumental in bridging the gap between our novel electrode manufacturing technique and its commercial application. Through the I-Corps program, we have refined our value proposition, identified key market segments, and developed a robust business model, all of which are crucial for successful commercialization. Additionally, the program has facilitated valuable connections with industry leaders and potential partners, accelerating our path to market. By leveraging the resources and mentorship provided by the I-Corps program, we are well-positioned to bring our innovative LIB technology to market, driving significant environmental, economic, and societal benefits. This journey through the I-Corps program underscores the importance of not only advancing scientific research but also ensuring that these innovations can effectively reach and benefit the wider society.

The intellectual outcomes of this project encompass five key aspects:

(1)    A robust business model with identified feasibility, viability, and desirability has been established based on customer discoveries.

(2)    Interactive communications and collaborative relationships have been built with leading manufacturing companies.

(3)    Comprehensive insights into protecting intellectual property via legal regulations have been gained to manage innovations and commercialization efforts strategically.

(4)    Our novel electrode manufacturing technique has been disseminated through multiple channels.

(5)    Prototype batteries based on electrodes manufactured by our novel electrode manufacturing technique have been assembled.

In addition, the I-Corps program has enriched educational experiences by integrating entrepreneurial training into academic curricula. The participating faculty, postdoc, graduate, and undergraduate students have gained firsthand experience in customer discovery, business model development, and market analysis, enhancing traditional engineering and science education. Industry collaborations have brought practical insights into the classroom, and project-based learning opportunities have fostered critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

The I-Corps program has made far-reaching impacts across multiple dimensions. By advancing LIB technology, fostering interdisciplinary research, supporting human resource development, enriching educational experiences, facilitating technology transfer, and contributing to societal well-being, the program has aligned closely with the mission of NSF I-corps. These outcomes underscore the importance of not only addressing technical challenges but also ensuring that these innovations can effectively reach and benefit the wider society. 

 


Last Modified: 06/12/2024
Modified by: Sunghwan Lee
